What do physicists mean by field theory

Quantum field theories (QFTs) are the main objects of study for a theoretical physicist, more so for those specializing in high energy physics. The standard model of particle physics is built on the framework of QFTs. Each of the fundamental particle (fermion or boson) is described by a QFT.

These theories are extremely important from a mathematical perspective. They find applications in topology of low-dimensional manifolds, representation theory, curve counting in enumerative geometry, symplectic geometry, algebraic and complex geometry etc. A complete mathematical understanding of quantum field theory is not available at present. Mathematicians (following Segal, Atiyah) have been successful in obtaining a rigorous definition of topological quantum field theories (TQFTs), a special class of QFTs.

Even though we don't understand QFTs, we can define "fields" which are the main ingredients of a field theory. In this post, we will define the notion of fields in classical theory. This theory is then quantized to obtain quantum field theory.
The setup for a field theory is :

  • Spacetime - A smooth, finite dimensional manifold \( M \). An example of \( M \) is the Minkowaski space \( M^{1,n} \). Often \( M \) is equipped with additional topological and geometric structures e.g metric, orientation, spin structure etc.
  • Fields - Variables of the field theory, in most cases a space of fields \( \mathcal{F} \)


We will take the following working definition of a (classical) field.
Definition: A field is a smooth section of a fiber bundle over \( M \)

Let \( \pi : E \rightarrow M \) be a fiber bundle over \( M \), then a field is a smooth map
$$ \phi : M \rightarrow E $$
such that \( \pi(\phi(x)) = x \) for all \( x \in M \). We denote this as -
$$ \phi \in C^{\infty}(E) $$

Examples:

  • A real scalar field is a smooth real-valued function on \( M \).
    $$ \phi : M \rightarrow \mathbb{R} $$ This is a section of trivial fiber bundle with fibers isomorphic to \( \mathbb{R} \).
  • A complex scalar field is a smooth complex-valued function on the spacetime. $$ \phi : M \rightarrow \mathbb{C} $$
  • More generally, we can consider \( X \)- valued smooth function, where \( X \) is another smooth manifold. $$ \Phi : M \rightarrow X $$ Such fields arise in sigma models. The \( \sigma \) - models, with target manifold \( X \) a Calabi-Yau or a Kahler manifold, are of particular interest to mathematicians.
  • Gauge theory - The setup for a gauge theory is a principal bundle with a connection. Let \( \pi : P \rightarrow M \) be a principal \( G \) - bundle.


Defintion: A connection \( \mathcal{A} \) on \( P \) is a \( \mathfrak{g} \) - valued 1-form, where \( \mathfrak{g} \) is the Lie algebra of the Lie group \( G \).
$$ \mathcal{A} \in C^{\infty}(P, T^{*}P) \otimes \mathfrak{g} $$
We call \( \mathcal{A} \) the gauge field with gauge group \( G \). The Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism is given by a circle bundle over the Minkowaski space where the electromagnetic potential is the connection.
In case of Yang-Mills theory, the gauge group is \( SU(n) \) and thus the fields are the connections on the \( SU(n) \)- principal bundles over the spacetime manifold. - Spinor fields - These theories are more complex than the others and require more structure as they encode the behavior of fermions. Let $latex M$ be equipped with a spinor structure, and let $$ \pi : S \rightarrow M $$ be a spinor bundle on \( M \). Then the spinor fields are the sections of \( S \). $$ \psi : M \rightarrow S $$ - Gravity - Let \( M \) be a Riemannian manifold. The fields in the theory of gravity, gravitational fields, are the metrics on \( M \). A metric \( g \) is a symmetric \( (0,2) \)-forms on \( M \). $$ g : M \rightarrow Symm^{(0,2)}(M) $$ - Supergravity - The Rarita-Schwinger field in supergravity theories, which describe a spin-\( 3/2 \) field, is given by a section of the twisted spinor bundle. $$ \psi : M \rightarrow S \otimes T^{*}M $$



In all the field theories, there exists a natural evaluation map,
$$ eval : \mathcal{F} \times M \rightarrow E $$ given by
$$ (\phi, x) \rightarrow \phi(x) $$ This post is full of mathematical (differential geometric, to be more accurate) jargon. The idea was to give a quick introduction of field theory to mathematicians (geometers).
